steps.title: üéØ Find the Verb!
steps.instruction: Identify the verb in the sentence below and pull it to the answer box!
steps.investigation: 'habe' comes from 'haben' (to have). This is not a condition verb, so it's an ACTION! You can review the most common condition verbs here.

steps.title: üëë Find the BOSS!
steps.instruction: Who or what is performing the action? Who or what is doing the thing?
steps.investigation: Who or what is performing the action? ‚Üí %ANSWER% (%ANSWER_EN%) is the BOSS.

steps.title: üéØ Find the VICTIM!
steps.instruction: To find the victim of the action, ask: Who or what is influenced by the verb?
steps.investigation: 'Whom or what do I have?' ‚Üí 'Bruder'. This is our VICTIM!

steps.title: ‚öñÔ∏è Choose the Case!
steps.instruction: Since we are working with an ACTION verb and you found a BOSS (Nominative) and a VICTIM, the victim must be put into the ACCUSATIVE case.
steps.result_template:
What you found out so far:
The victim is %VICTIM_NOUN% (%VICTIM_GENDER%).
Masculine: der ‚Üí den / ein ‚Üí einen
Feminine: die ‚Üí die / eine ‚Üí eine
Neuter: das ‚Üí das / ein ‚Üí ein
steps.investigation: Correct! Because 'Bruder' is masculine, 'ein' becomes 'einen' in the accusative case.

caseTitle: üïµÔ∏è THE CASE: 'The dog helps the man.'

steps.title: üéØ Find the Verb!
steps.instruction: Identify the verb in the sentence below and pull it to the answer box!
steps.investigation: 'hilft' comes from 'helfen' (to help). This verb is a special exception that requires the DATIVE case, not Accusative!

steps.title: üëë Find the BOSS!
steps.instruction: Who or what is performing the action?
steps.investigation: Who or what is helping? ‚Üí %ANSWER% (%ANSWER_EN%) is the BOSS (Nominative).

steps.title: ü§ù Find the 'Helper' Object!
steps.instruction: Since 'helfen' is a special Dative verb, we don't ask 'Whom or what?'. Instead, we ask 'To whom?'
steps.investigation: 'To whom does the dog help?' ‚Üí 'Mann'. This object is in the DATIVE case.

steps.title: ‚öñÔ∏è Choose the Case!
steps.instruction: Because 'helfen' is a DATIVE verb, the object receiving the action must be put into the DATIVE case.
steps.result_template:
What you found out so far:
The object is %VICTIM_NOUN% (%VICTIM_GENDER%).
Masculine: der ‚Üí dem / ein ‚Üí einem
Feminine: die ‚Üí der / eine ‚Üí einer
Neuter: das ‚Üí dem / ein ‚Üí einem
steps.investigation: Correct! Because 'Mann' is masculine, 'der' becomes 'dem' in the dative case.
